Zélus

A synchronous language with ODEs

›

Compiler

Zélus is a synchronous language extended with Ordinary Differential Equations (ODEs) to model hybrid systems with complex interaction between discrete-time and continuous-time dynamics. It shares the basic principles of the synchronous language Lustre with language and compiler features from Lucid Synchrone (type inference, hierarchical automata, and signals). To that, it add the possibily to The compiler is written in OCaml and is structured as a series of source-to-source and traceable transformations that ultimately yield statically scheduled sequential code. Continuous components are simulated using off-the-shelf numerical solvers (here Sundials CVODE) and, for the moment, two built-in solvers (ode23 and ode45).

If you want an access to the up-to-date development repository on INRIA GitLab (https://gitlab.inria.fr/parkas/zelus), send us a mail.

Research

Zélus is used to experiment with new techniques for building hybrid modelers like Simulink/Stateflow and Modelica on top of a synchronous language. The language exploits novel techniques for defining the dynamic and static semantics of hybrid modelers; it uses several dedicated type systems to insure safety properties like the absence of discontinuities during integration and the ability to generate statically scheduled (sequential) code. In particular, all discrete computations must be aligned to zero-crossing events; programs with causality loops and uninitialized values are statically rejected.
